data.title: Cinema Parrot Disco
data.meta_description: Posts about Woody Harrelson written by table9mutant
data.text:
Three decent 2023 releases today‚Ä¶

Missing (2023)

Directed by Will Merrick & Nick Johnson

Starring: Storm Reid, Joaquim de Almeida, Ken Leung, Amy Landecker, Daniel Henney, Nia Long

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

Its plot follows June Allen, a teenager who tries to find her missing mother after she disappears on vacation in Colombia with her new boyfriend.

My Opinion:

Really enjoyed this, as well as the film Searching. Thought being set entirely on screens would be annoying but it works very well. Both have solid stories, which is more important than the screen gimmick. I love a fun mystery thriller! Used to get films like this more often. I miss them. Searching was a bit better but both were very enjoyable & I‚Äôd happily watch further standalone sequels.

Oh yeah ‚Äì just realized that‚Äôs the girl who was the friend in The Last Of Us. I liked that episode. And I liked that dude‚Äôs character in the below photo.

My Rating: 7.5/10

Renfield (2023)

Directed by Chris McKay

Based on Dracula by Bram Stoker

Starring: Nicholas Hoult, Awkwafina, Ben Schwartz, Shohreh Aghdashloo, Brandon Scott Jones, Adrian Martinez, Nicolas Cage

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDb)

Renfield, Dracula‚Äôs henchman and inmate at the lunatic asylum for decades, longs for a life away from the Count, his various demands, and all of the bloodshed that comes with them.

My Opinion:

For some reason I wasn‚Äôt expecting this to be the Deadpool of vampire movies but I had a lot of fun with the OTT comedic violence & Nicolas Cage actually being less wacky than usual. Nicholas Hoult was funny & I really liked Awkwafina‚Äòs character plus they worked well together. I love horror comedy, though, so can see this not working for everyone. One of 2023‚Äôs more enjoyable films for me.

My Rating: 7/10

Champions (2023)

Directed by Bobby Farrelly

Based on Campeones by Javier Fesser & David Marqu√©s

Starring: Woody Harrelson, Kaitlin Olson, Ernie Hudson, Cheech Marin

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

The film stars Woody Harrelson as a temperamental minor-league basketball coach who, after an arrest, must coach a team of players with intellectual disabilities as community service.

My Opinion:

Enjoyed this. Can‚Äôt say it‚Äôs something we haven‚Äôt seen a lot (angry guy is ordered to work with people who are seen as less fortunate & sees the error of his ways & becomes a good person ‚Äì Holy shit, how many times have we see this?!). But what can I say? I like a feelgood film with genuinely likeable characters & this ticks those boxes. A predictably pleasant watch.

My Rating: 7/10

I‚Äôve managed to already review all the movies I‚Äôve watched this month. Yay, me! So I decided to post them all this week instead of waiting for my monthly roundup post.

Three quickies below. One movie I quite liked, one movie I thought was a bit dull but had a good performance, and one movie I think I kind of hated. Of course, the one I liked the most is the one that had no Oscar nominations.

Where The Crawdads Sing (2022)

Directed by Olivia Newman

Based on Where the Crawdads Sing by Delia Owens

Starring: Daisy Edgar-Jones, Taylor John Smith, Harris Dickinson, Michael Hyatt, Sterling Macer, Jr., Jojo Regina, Garret Dillahunt, Ahna O‚ÄôReilly, David Strathairn

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

The story follows an abandoned yet defiant girl, Kya, who raises herself to adulthood in a North Carolina marshland, becoming a naturalist in the process. When the town‚Äôs hotshot is found dead, she is the prime suspect and is tried for murder.

My Opinion:

How is Marsh Girl less socially awkward than I am?!

This is one of those movies I really liked but can‚Äôt explain why. Some of it is ridiculous. ‚ÄúMarsh Girl‚Äù is far too pretty & miraculously smart & of course learns how to read in a heartwarming montage & accomplishes far more in life than most of us ever will. But I liked her and I liked the nice boyfriend & the couple from the town who helped her and I liked the story. That‚Äôs good enough for me. And I always like when assholes get what they deserve. Hell yeah. And I loved the ending. One of the better films I‚Äôve seen so far this year.

My Rating: 7.5/10

To Leslie (2022)

Directed by Michael Morris

Starring: Andrea Riseborough, Andre Royo, Owen Teague, Stephen Root, James Landry Hebert, Marc Maron, Allison Janney

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

The film stars Andrea Riseborough as Leslie Rowland, a single mother and alcoholic who squanders all the prize money she received after winning the lottery. She soon finds the chance to redeem herself when a motel owner offers her a job.

My Opinion:

Had to see what all the fuss was about. Am a bit baffled by the huge amount of celebrity praise as it‚Äôs a quite average ‚Äúaddiction movie‚Äù that we‚Äôve seen many times. Think Andrea Riseborough was worthy of her Oscar nomination, though, as she did give a really good performance. She was especially good in the second half of the movie, which was much better than its very slow start. Worth checking out for Riseborough and for the second half of the film, which ended up winning me over with a strong ending.

My Rating: 7/10

Triangle Of Sadness (2022)

Directed & Written by Ruben √ñstlund

Starring: Harris Dickinson, Charlbi Dean, Dolly de Leon, Zlatko Buriƒá, Iris Berben, Vicki Berlin, Henrik Dorsin, Jean-Christophe Folly, Amanda Walker, Oliver Ford Davies, Sunnyi Melles, Woody Harrelson

Plot Synopsis:

Rich people suck. And vomit. And shit.

My Opinion:

I now have a least favorite Best Picture nominee out of the six I‚Äôve seen this year. EEAAO was my previous least favorite so I‚Äôm feeling very out of touch as I can‚Äôt quite figure out what people saw in these. What am I missing?

This started out okay in Part 1. Charlbi Dean (RIP) & Harris Dickinson played the only characters I almost gave a shit about. Okay, I know we‚Äôre meant to hate them all but do we really need so many movies stating the fucking obvious about the rich? Society is never going to change. I guess I‚Äôd just rather watch them get eaten by zombies in Land Of The Dead or something than see them vomiting & shitting all over the place. Or, speaking of society, I‚Äôd rather watch Society (1989). I thought The Menu was a bit of a mess but Triangle made me appreciate that similar story a bit more, although I think they both failed to make much of a point and aren‚Äôt as clever as they think. And I‚Äôd heard that this one was fun? It was far too long & I kept checking how much time was remaining once the puking & shitting started (there‚Äôs still loads of time left after that). It‚Äôs probably the least fun I‚Äôve had watching a movie in a long time.

Okay, I wasn‚Äôt a fan of this movie but I didn‚Äôt absolutely hate it. I did like Charlbi Dean & Harris Dickinson as mentioned. And I thought Woody Harrelson was pretty great, although he‚Äôs played this sort of drunk dude so many times (but he‚Äôs so good at that so that‚Äôs fine). And, like most everyone, I also liked Dolly de Leon and the whole ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the Captain‚Äù thing in Part 3. That was good. So I‚Äôve given an extra half a star for these four people. The bad just far outweighed the good in this film for me. Part 1 & 3 were bearable but I thought Part 2 would never end. I‚Äôm glad I watched it as I try to watch all the Best Picture nominees but I wouldn‚Äôt want to suffer through this one a second time.

My Rating: 5.5/10

Zombieland: Double Tap (2019)

Directed by Ruben Fleischer

Starring: Woody Harrelson, Jesse Eisenberg, Abigail Breslin, Emma Stone, Rosario Dawson, Zoey Deutch, Luke Wilson

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDb)

Columbus, Tallahassee, Wichita, and Little Rock move to the American heartland as they face off against evolved zombies, fellow survivors, and the growing pains of the snarky makeshift family.

My Opinion:

I really enjoyed the first Zombieland. It even just made it into my list of My Top Ten Horror Comedies. Is the sequel as good as the first film? Of course not. Are they ever? You‚Äôre talking ten years since the last one, though. We‚Äôve had zombie overload since then. We‚Äôve had almost ten years of The Walking Dead, which gets more and more and MORE shit every year (why do I keep watching it?!). Double Tap has nothing that feels the tiniest bit original, while I think the first film managed a bit of originality despite not being the first zom-com. I‚Äôm a little disappointed but admit that I like these characters and enjoyed seeing them again. Well, maybe not Jesse Eisenberg (Twat).

I have sequel review burnout. I‚Äôm running out of things to say about cashgrab sequels & reboots & remakes. I‚Äôm also bored with October Horror Month. I want to review the non-horror stuff I‚Äôve seen lately. Joker. Judy. Hustlers. The Farewell. Terminator: Dark Fate, which I saw last night and am hating more and more as I think about it. Leave classics the fuck alone! I think Dark Fate is what‚Äôs made me lose the desire to write about pointless sequels. Double Tap didn‚Äôt piss me off like Dark Fate, though. It wasn‚Äôt a sequel that we needed but there‚Äôs no harm in it.

Meh. Woody Harrelson is by far the best thing about these two movies and I really enjoyed his character once again. I could kind of take or leave the rest of them, though, and I don‚Äôt think the new additions were anything special. Zoey Deutch was fun but kind of wasted as I think she deserved a better character. And‚Ä¶ Hmm. Zombies. There are zombies. The movie is actually less gory than The Walking Dead but the zombie kills are more fun. Maybe The Walking Dead should add some humor to stop the show being so damn boring.

My Rating: 7/10

My rating is too high. I think I‚Äôm just being nice because I like Woody.

Oh, and they opened this movie with Metallica‚Äôs Master Of Puppets. So we‚Äôll say my rating got an extra half a point for Woody and half a point for using one of Metallica‚Äôs best songs‚Ä¶

Happy Birthday to Woody Harrelson, who turns 58 today.

I like Harrelson but I can‚Äôt say I was always a fan. But his roles and movies keep getting better and better. I‚Äôm glad he‚Äôs finally being taken more seriously as an actor. I think he‚Äôs one of those actors who people will eventually realize was underrated for many years. I think being in fairly controversial films maybe didn‚Äôt help at the time, like Natural Born Killers & The People Vs. Larry Flynt, but he was fantastic in those. At least he was an Oscar nominee for Flynt, I guess. I‚Äôd like to see him get an Oscar someday. He‚Äôs proven he can do any sort of role; from comedy to serious drama to complete and utter psycho.

So I figured I‚Äôd do a full ranking of all the Harrelson films I‚Äôve seen. I‚Äôll be honest and say that I could really do with re-watching most of those outside of the Top Ten. Maybe some would end up in the ten on a re-watch. We‚Äôll see. But, for now, these are My Top Ten Woody Harrelson Movies (ranked by how much I like the movie, not the role):

22-11

22. Friends With Benefits

21. Kingpin

20. Seven Pounds

19. The Glass Castle

18. Doc Hollywood

17. EDtv

16. Indecent Proposal

15. 2012

14. Now You See Me

13. Anger Management

12. Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me

11. A Scanner Darkly

TOP TEN:

10. White Men Can‚Äôt Jump

9. Seven Psychopaths

8. The Hunger Games Movies

7. The People Vs. Larry Flynt

6. The Edge Of Seventeen

5. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri

4. War For The Planet Of The Apes

3. Solo: A Star Wars Story

2. Zombieland

1. Natural Born Killers

Some I‚Äôve Not Seen:

Wildcats, Moneytrain, Wag The Dog, The Thin Red Line, Palmetto, After The Sunset, North Country, A Prairie Home Companion, No Country For Old Men, Semi-Pro, Transsiberian, Out Of The Furnace, Free Birds, Triple 9, Now You See Me 2, The Duel, LBJ, Wilson, Venom

And I won‚Äôt count his uncredited roles in She‚Äôs Having A Baby & L.A. Story

TV Shows:

I‚Äôm not forgetting, of course, his role as Woody on Cheers. I miss classic American TV here in the UK! It was weird to see him go from that sweet, lovable role to things like Natural Born Killers. And I know a lot of people loved True Detective but I hated it with a passion. I‚Äôm glad it helped keep him so popular, though.

It was fun watching him at Wimbledon the other day. People were going crazy on Twitter over the announcers commentating on everything Harrelson was doing. I saw more of Harrelson at Wimbledon than I did of any actual tennis.

Solo: A Star Wars Story (2018)

Directed by Ron Howard

Starring: Alden Ehrenreich, Woody Harrelson, Emilia Clarke, Donald Glover, Thandie Newton, Phoebe Waller-Bridge, Joonas Suotamo, Paul Bettany

Music by John Powell & John Williams

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDb)

During an adventure into a dark criminal underworld, Han Solo meets his future copilot Chewbacca and encounters Lando Calrissian years before joining the Rebellion.

My Opinion:

I saw this at midnight last night. I‚Äôm exhausted! But I suppose I better do a quickie review before America gets to see this tonight (is that right?). Because I‚Äôm sure everyone is just dying to know my opinion as there‚Äôll be NO other reviews to be found for this movie anywhere. Yeah, the other reviews will be much more detailed than mine. You won‚Äôt find that here. I‚Äôll make this very quick and just let you know if I liked the latest Star Wars movie or not.

Yep! I liked it. I really really liked it. Not sure yet if I loved it, but‚Ä¶ Maybe. I need to see it again. Here‚Äôs how I feel about all the new Star Wars movies (I‚Äôve linked to my full reviews):

‚Ä¢ The Force Awakens: LOVED it. Easily my favorite of the new ones.

‚Ä¢ Rogue One: Certainly didn‚Äôt hate it but didn‚Äôt love it. Liked it okay but, overall, it just didn‚Äôt work for me. Felt the least ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù to me.

‚Ä¢ The Last Jedi: Wasn‚Äôt happy with this at first. It has grown on me. I certainly like it much more than a lot of people seemed to but, depending on what they do with the final film, I could end up liking this one much more or much less. Really hope they do the final film right (I want it to be more like The Force Awakens).

My ranking? I don‚Äôt yet know until the final film but it‚Äôs currently probably The Force Awakens, then The Last Jedi or Solo (time will tell so I‚Äôll make them a tie at the moment) and then Rogue One. My hubby‚Äôs order (HUGE Star Wars nut), if you‚Äôre interested, is currently: The Force Awakens, Solo, Rogue One, The Last Jedi. I was surprised he has Solo in second place so far but he did thoroughly enjoy it.

So onto Solo‚Ä¶ As most people have said so far, this movie is a lot of fun. There seems to be a big backlash against this movie before people have even seen it. I truly don‚Äôt understand that. Is it just because they didn‚Äôt like The Last Jedi?? Wow, people are hard to please. I was shocked that the midnight showings for this at my cinema were completely dead. One screen had only six people! I love Star Wars and, no, I really don‚Äôt want to see its legacy ruined. Yes, I worry that The Last Jedi has started down that path. But let‚Äôs see how they handle the final film. And, in the meantime, let‚Äôs spend some time having fun with Han, Chewbacca & Lando since they‚Äôre fantastic characters we all love. I also saw a lot of people say ‚ÄúOh, people are saying Solo is fun. That just means it‚Äôs bad‚Äù. Huh? Since when did people decide that movies aren‚Äôt meant to be fun anymore?! I want movies to be fun. I want to be entertained. Fun doesn‚Äôt automatically mean bad.

I think the most important thing to me was that they‚Äôd get our most beloved characters right. I think we all had our doubts about Alden Ehrenreich but I think he did a good job. Was he the perfect person for this role? Maybe not. But who could be? Han Solo is one of the most iconic (and coolest) characters of all time. Who can possibly do Han Solo justice?? I had no problem with Ehrenreich ‚Äì I liked him as Han. And Donald Glover is great as Lando but I think we had already accepted him based on the trailers. He‚Äôs cool as f*^k. I loved seeing these two characters meeting and, even as I write this, I‚Äôm probably liking this movie even more as I think of young Han, Lando, and Chewbacca all meeting for the first time. I adored all their scenes together.

I thought all the new characters were pretty great as well. I‚Äôm not sure that I have any new absolute favorites but it‚Äôs very hard to top all of the original trilogy characters. I‚Äôm not going to get into the new additions, however, as I wish to remain completely spoiler free. I‚Äôll just say that I liked the history that Han had with Qi‚Äôra (Emilia Clarke), Woody Harrelson and his team of ‚Äúcan they be trusted?‚Äù misfits were a joy and the perfect fit to team up with Han & Lando, and the baddies were quite effective ‚Äì they looked the part and were menacing.

What else can I say? This movie gave me what I wanted. It‚Äôll never top the original trilogy but no new Star Wars movie ever will. I don‚Äôt expect that from any of the new movies. I think Ron Howard has done a great job with Solo, especially considering that it was such a troubled production. It stays very faithful to & respectful of the Star Wars legacy and does all the existing characters justice. There are some great ‚Äúfan service‚Äù bits that are a real pleasure but don‚Äôt feel at all forced (they aren‚Äôt the type you‚Äôll roll your eyes at ‚Äì they‚Äôre just fun). Yeah. Fun! This movie is fun. Fun is good. Fun is what I wanted. It‚Äôs okay to have fun sometimes! Solo: A Star Wars Story is a good film and, for me, it‚Äôs a welcome addition to the Star Wars universe.

My Rating: 8/10

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri (2017)

Directed & Written by Martin McDonagh

Starring: Frances McDormand, Caleb Landry Jones, Kerry Condon, Sam Rockwell, Darrell Britt-Gibson, Woody Harrelson, Abbie Cornish, Lucas Hedges, ≈Ωeljko Ivanek, Peter Dinklage, John Hawkes, Samara Weaving, Clarke Peters

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

The film follows a mother who, when the police in her town fail to find a suspect in her daughter‚Äôs murder, rents three billboards to call public attention to the unsolved crime, polarizing the community.

My Opinion:

I watched this the other day as part of a ‚Äúdouble feature‚Äù with Coco (which I reviewed HERE). I love Pixar and was expecting to like Coco far more but I preferred Three Billboards. It‚Äôs a great film! I don‚Äôt know why but maybe it‚Äôs because my expectations were low whereas they were very high for Coco.

It‚Äôs that time of year in the UK when we get the ‚ÄúOscar-worthy‚Äù stuff like this. Because what better way to make the shittiest month of the year even MORE depressing than by releasing all the dark & dreary Oscar dramas?! Manchester By The Sea? Hell yeah! Just what I want to watch in f*^king January! But I kind of loved Three Billboards. It‚Äôs another ‚ÄúOscar drama‚Äù but it‚Äôs so well-written and wonderfully acted and the dark humor throughout it really made it a much more rewarding watch (for me, at least) than the usual heavy Oscar dramas. Okay, I know the Oscar nominations aren‚Äôt out yet but this will most likely be one of them and, at the moment, I can say I‚Äôd be happy to see it win. We‚Äôll see what it‚Äôs up against ‚Äì most of the films still aren‚Äôt out here yet.

Where do I begin? With the acting? I loved everyone in this. I‚Äôm a bit weird in that I don‚Äôt care too much about the acting in a film, as long as it isn‚Äôt terrible and as long as it‚Äôs not someone I can‚Äôt stand the sight of (like Gwyneth Paltrow or something). But, man ‚Äì everyone did a brilliant job in this. Our main three, Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson & Sam Rockwell, were insanely good. Like, I want to hug them and thank them for being in this movie. Seriously. And I hate a lot of actors! When did Woody Harrelson get so great??? I loved him in Edge Of Seventeen as well. He‚Äôs going to end up a favorite actor of mine at this rate. I wouldn‚Äôt have expected that ten years ago. Everyone else as well, though, even down to the small parts ‚Äì all were great. Perfect casting. I‚Äôd love to see the acting win plenty of Oscars for this film.

I‚Äôm not sure why my expectations were so low for this film. I really enjoyed Martin McDonagh‚Äôs In Bruges. I also thought Seven Psychopaths, though flawed, was pretty good overall. Three Billboards is now easily my favorite (yes, even over In Bruges). And no Colin Farrell in this! Yay! I‚Äôd recommend this to anyone who was a fan of McDonagh‚Äôs previous two films as it has the same sort of style. However, this is much darker material (a teenage girl is murdered) and the emotions feel more genuine than in his previous films. The movie gets the right balance between drama & humor and it wasn‚Äôt a ‚Äúheavy‚Äù watch in the way I was expecting. I‚Äôm actually not a fan of things like Fargo (I never finished it) and preferred the way that these characters felt more real to me. I suppose it‚Äôs a combination of the acting and the writing, which has come together perfectly in Three Billboards whereas McDonagh‚Äôs other two films didn‚Äôt work quite as well overall. I‚Äôm now really looking forward to seeing more of his films in the future. And as he likes to re-use actors, I hope he sticks with McDormand, Harrelson & Rockwell.

My Rating: 8/10

The Glass Castle by Jeannette Walls

What It‚Äôs About: (via Wikipedia)

The Glass Castle is a 2005 memoir by Jeannette Walls. The book recounts the unconventional, poverty-stricken upbringing Walls and her siblings had at the hands of their deeply dysfunctional parents.

My Thoughts:

I read this as, which you may notice by my list at the end of this review, I‚Äôm reading books before their movie adaptations are released this year. The Glass Castle, starring Brie Larson, Woody Harrelson & Naomi Watts, is out today in the U.S. and October 6th in the U.K. I‚Äôm a fan of Larson, especially after the fantastic Room as well as Short Term 12 (which was also from the director of The Glass Castle, Destin Daniel Cretton). So, even though ‚Äútrue story dramas‚Äù don‚Äôt normally appeal to me, I decided to give this a read since I‚Äôll happily watch a movie with this film‚Äôs cast. I didn‚Äôt expect the book to quite possibly be my very favorite that I‚Äôve read so far this year. But, I think it probably is. What a pleasant surprise.

I liked the way in which Walls wrote her story. It‚Äôs very matter-of-fact and doesn‚Äôt seem to be passing judgement on her parents & the way in which they chose to raise their children. Like a lot of people raised in small-town American Midwest, my childhood was pretty straightforward (and pretty damn boring). Not rich, not poor, working parents, regularly attended school, followed all the rules & the ‚Äúsocietal norms‚Äù, etc. The Walls family are unlike any I‚Äôve ever personally known and I found their story fascinating. I suppose there are other nomadic families in America but it‚Äôs a world I‚Äôve never experienced & can‚Äôt even begin to imagine. The Walls family moved from place to place all across America, sometimes homeless & living out in the open, rarely holding down regular jobs despite having the ability to work (including the mother having the qualifications for teaching) and despite the fact that their children had to dig their classmates‚Äô uneaten lunches out of the trash at school in order to have anything to eat. I was often shocked by the horrendous neglect endured by Jeannette, her two sisters, and her brother (and amazed that these children were never taken away from their parents). However, as I said, Jeannette never really speaks poorly of her parents ‚Äì she just tells her story in a straightforward manner without the need to embellish things. Their story is so outrageous that I don‚Äôt think you could make up half of the odd things their parents did. Yet Jeannette does still give us glimpses of the love their parents had for them, especially from her father through his many broken promises that I think he himself may have genuinely believed he‚Äôd keep even though his children knew he never would.

This is a hard book to describe without making it sound horribly depressing but it‚Äôs not really that way at all. It‚Äôs truly amusing and at times had me smiling at some of the bizarre things this family went through (like when they try to move a piano into their house). Jeannette‚Äôs parents, though they will sometimes make you very angry if you read this, are truly a couple of unique characters & free spirits. It‚Äôs highly unusual for me to enjoy (or even bother to read) a true story but, as they say, sometimes life is stranger than fiction. Do they say that? Hmm. Well, someone said that. Sounds like something Jeannette‚Äôs father would say. I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôve talked anyone into reading this but I do highly recommend it. It‚Äôs frustrating. It‚Äôs uplifting. It‚Äôll make you angry. It‚Äôll make you smile. It‚Äôll make you shake your head in disbelief. You won‚Äôt know whether you want to hug or punch the parents (most likely the latter). But it‚Äôs also not soppy or trying to be some big tearjerker, which is the kind of thing that gets on my nerves. It‚Äôs just a well-written story of a girl who somehow managed to survive & to thrive after living a truly unusual childhood with two very eccentric parents. The movie has ‚Äúmeh‚Äù reviews so far & the below trailer doesn‚Äôt really blow me away (although I‚Äôll still watch it). So, if you can, READ THE BOOK FIRST.

My Rating: 4.5/5

Books I‚Äôve Read So Far In 2017 (ranked from least favorite to favorite‚Ä¶)

‚Äì Tape by Steven Camden

‚Äì The Sisters by Claire Douglas

‚Äì We Were Liars by E. Lockhart

‚Äì If I Stay by Gayle Forman

‚Äì The Circle by Dave Eggers

‚Äì The Snowman by Jo Nesbo

‚Äì The Chrysalids by John Wyndham

‚Äì Thirteen Reasons Why by Jay Asher

‚Äì Finders Keepers by Stephen King

‚Äì The Dinner by Herman Koch

‚Äì The Handmaid‚Äôs Tale by Margaret Atwood

‚Äì The Dark Tower: The Gunslinger by Stephen King

‚Äì Blaze by Stephen King

‚Äì A Monster Calls by Patrick Ness

‚Äì Big Little Lies by Liane Moriarty

‚Äì Everything, Everything by Nicola Yoon

‚Äì Murder On The Orient Express by Agatha Christie

‚Äì Annihilation by Jeff VanderMeer

‚Äì All The Bright Places by Jennifer Niven

‚Äì The Glass Castle by Jeannette Walls

Currently Reading: End Of Watch by Stephen King (book 3 of the Mr. Mercedes trilogy)

The Edge Of Seventeen (2016)

Directed by Kelly Fremon Craig

Starring: Hailee Steinfeld, Haley Lu Richardson, Hayden Szeto, Blake Jenner, Woody Harrelson, Kyra Sedgwick

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDB)

High-school life gets even more unbearable for Nadine when her best friend, Krista, starts dating her older brother.

My Opinion:

Yes! Another funny, well-written, smart ‚Äúteen movie‚Äù. I reviewed The DUFF last week, which I really enjoyed despite my teen years being far far behind me, and commented that I hoped more teen movies would go in that direction as I do still enjoy a good one. Trust me ‚Äì no matter how old you are you never forget high school. It‚Äôs a traumatic time! I think I‚Äôll forever feel like it was only yesterday that I finally graduated & escaped that f*^king place.

So, yeah ‚Äì I wasn‚Äôt exactly the Homecoming Queen and I could totally relate to Hailee Steinfeld‚Äôs self-loathing, angst-filled, neurotic nutjob in The Edge Of Seventeen. Hubby was like ‚ÄúI think she may be even more messed up than you!‚Äù. Hahaha! Nice. Funny. Seriously, though ‚Äì I‚Äôd have been friends with this character as a teen. Okay, I lie ‚Äì I WAS this character (but not as crazy ‚Äì Holy shit, Steinfeld‚Äôs character is HIGH MAINTENANCE!).

For those who may get annoyed by phoney teen angst movies, don‚Äôt automatically avoid this one. This is teen angst done right. It has the right balance of humor & of more serious issues. Think a cross between The DUFF (pure comedy) and The Perks Of Being A Wallflower (fantastic but a little too serious). The characters come across as genuine and I think it will speak to an audience of all ages from 15 or so & up. I do think certain teen films nowadays are written by people my age (like Perks), which is cool as it means people my age end up liking them but I‚Äôm not sure if they all work for actual modern teens. I think The Edge Of Seventeen avoids this problem. I can see a lot of friends my age liking this and, judging by the laughs & reactions of the much younger crowd in my cinema who made me feel very old, the younger generation seemed to be enjoying it a lot as well. I can find very little information on this film‚Äôs writer & director, Kelly Fremon Craig, but I‚Äôd hazard a guess that she‚Äôs written a bit of herself into these characters? I could be wrong but writing from experience often seems to make the most believable characters & she‚Äôs done an excellent job here. I‚Äôll happily watch more of her work! Hopefully the positive buzz from this film is getting her noticed.

Just a quick FYI: the language & situations make this one not suitable for pre & early teens. It‚Äôs rated 15 in the UK and I think it‚Äôs rated R in the US?? Typical uptight America ‚Äì R is too strict for this & means that 15 & 16 year-olds are missing out on a good movie. Maybe they should‚Äôve added some guns & violence as opposed to swearing & sex talk, huh? Then it would be rated G in America! I‚Äôve often thought the American rating system needs a rating in the middle, like a UK 15, which I think is the right sort of rating for this one. Sorry for the mini-rant‚Ä¶ üòâ Back to the movie!

Besides Hailee Steinfeld‚Äôs darkly humorous unhappy teen, we have her parents and a very rocky relationship with her mother, her best friend who suddenly starts dating her attractive & popular brother who gets on her nerves, her crush, her teacher, and a boy who has a crush on her. They‚Äôre all great but the two stand-outs are Hayden Szeto as the adorably awkward boy with a crush on her and Woody Harrelson as the doesn‚Äôt-give-a-fuck teacher she confides in (probably due to seeing a bit of her own pessimistic attitude in him).

The chemistry between Steinfeld‚Äôs & Harrelson‚Äôs characters is great and I loved their complexity. There‚Äôs no sappy ‚Äúteacher gives student meaningful life lesson‚Äù bullshit going on here. In fact, they speak quite horribly to each other & it‚Äôs hilarious. You can tell that, despite clearly thinking she‚Äôs a pain in the ass, Harrelson‚Äôs character also has a huge soft spot for this fucked-up kid. Both of these characters are two of the absolute best I‚Äôve seen in a film this year and are why this shouldn‚Äôt be dismissed due to being a ‚Äúteen movie‚Äù. Oh, and Hayden Szeto‚Äôs character with a crush on Steinfeld is probably the most likable character in a film this year. He‚Äôs hilariously, awkwardly adorable. Who is this guy?? He‚Äôs been in hardly anything! Put him in more movies! I‚Äôd have totally loved having a boy like him have a crush on me in high school. Damn you, Steinfeld ‚Äì he‚Äôs a sweetheart. Date him! It‚Äôs like Molly Ringwald not wanting Jon Cryer in Pretty In Pink! Man, teenage girls are idiots sometimes. Anyway ‚Äì Hayden Szeto, Woody Harrelson, and Hailee Steinfeld are all amazing in this but probably won‚Äôt get recognition due to the film being part of the teen genre.

Summary:

I‚Äôve rambled on about this movie long enough. I‚Äôve realized now that my saying this is something in between The DUFF & The Perks Of Being A Wallflower isn‚Äôt quite accurate. The Edge Of Seventeen is more like The Way Way Back with a girl instead of a boy as the central character & Harrelson filling the Sam Rockwell role in this one (their characters are quite different personality-wise but equally fantastic). I feel that teen movies get dismissed, especially if a girl is the central character, but this movie deserves recognition. If you liked The Way Way Back (I loved that one), you should like this one as well no matter what age or sex you are. Movies like these give me hope that maybe some modern teenagers will turn out alright after all & I appreciate filmmakers who credit them with some intelligence & don‚Äôt dumb their movies down for them. I still remember being a teen & I like to think I wasn‚Äôt a total idiot. And anyone who says they didn‚Äôt have a hard time in high school is a liar. Teen angst is real, people! I‚Äôm happy to say that The Edge Of Seventeen handles the angst in a realistic, humorous, and at times heartbreaking fashion.

My Rating: 8/10

You know I gotta end this with the brilliant Stevie Nicks song from my own teen years, which is not in this movie whatsoever. Wait ‚Äì I wasn‚Äôt a teen yet when this was released‚Ä¶ I just added several years onto my age there! Oops. Whatever. I love this song. üôÇ

Natural Born Killers (1994)

Directed by Oliver Stone

Story by Quentin Tarantino

Starring: Woody Harrelson, Juliette Lewis, Robert Downey Jr, Tommy Lee Jones, Tom Sizemore, Rodney Dangerfield

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

A satirical black comedy crime film that tells the story of two victims of traumatic childhoods who became lovers and mass murderers, and are irresponsibly glorified by the mass media.

My Opinion:

Here we are with movie number three of my 2016 Blind Spot picks. I can‚Äôt believe I‚Äôve actually managed to review one each month so far! (the previous two were An Education & Summer Wars). Other than The Doors & Platoon, I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve really liked any Oliver Stone films all that much so I went into this one with fairly low expectations. Plus, I‚Äôve never exactly loved either Woody Harrelson or Juliette Lewis. Well, I have to say that I liked this one quite a bit and both those actors have gone up a little in my estimation (22 years later!).

I suppose it helps that Quentin Tarantino wrote the story? He wasn‚Äôt involved with the actual screenplay (I read that they changed his story quite a lot) but this movie has the overall vibe of the films he directed ‚Äì not just in the extreme violence, of course, but also in the rich characters & dialogue.

I think it‚Äôs difficult to make a satire on our obsession with violence that then uses excessive violence to get its point across. Does this movie glorify violence just as much as it claims the media does, thanks to shows such as the film‚Äôs American Maniacs as hosted by Robert Downey Jr‚Äôs character? I read that, at first, this movie was going to be a straight-up action film before Stone decided to turn it into a satirical black comedy. I think changing the direction of the movie was a very wise decision. Actually, this is what I read at Wikipedia ‚Äì I can see why he changed his mind:

‚ÄúAs the project developed however, incidents such as the O.J. Simpson case, the Menendez brothers case, the Tonya Harding/Nancy Kerrigan incident, the Rodney King incident, and the Federal assault of the Branch Davidian sect all took place. Stone came to feel that the media was heavily involved in the outcome of all of these cases, and that the media had become an all-pervasive entity which marketed violence and suffering for the good of ratings. As such, he changed the tone of the movie from one of simple action to a satirical critique of the media in general.‚Äù

I think the movie very much gets its point across and is even more relevant today as violence seems to be at an all-time high but, also, scenes of graphic violence are even more immediately accessible now than in 1994 thanks to the explosion of the Internet. It‚Äôs not some true-crime TV show (hosted by Downey Jr with, I gotta say, a really annoying fake Australian accent) that we have to worry about these days. Hell, American Maniacs looks like a Saturday morning kids‚Äô cartoon compared to today‚Äôs video games & torture porn films never mind the disturbing clips of real-life violence which are far too readily available online thanks to everyone having their own damn video cameras in their phones. (Off Topic Rant: Man, I love my phone but wish I could time travel back to 1985 when peoples‚Äô private lives weren‚Äôt being constantly recorded & uploaded for all to see. Kardashian-free 1980‚Äôs life sounds like a damn utopia now! Rant Over). So, Natural Born Killers is more relevant today but also wouldn‚Äôt actually work if made now as it‚Äôs no longer satire. Watching it now was quite scary, in a way, as I imagine it felt far-fetched in 1994? Now it just feels like one of those Making A Murderer type of true story documentaries that are so popular on Netflix.

I‚Äôm actually a huge wuss when it comes to violence in movies (I watch Tarantino‚Äôs with my hands over my face half the time) but am more accepting when the movie has a message like I feel this one does. There‚Äôs lots of blood in this but I was able to watch it all as it‚Äôs not as ‚Äúgory‚Äù as Tarantino-directed films (which do glorify violence but are so cleverly written that I can‚Äôt help but love them anyway as a fan of film). Will someone go on a murder spree after watching this? Maybe. But someone who does that would‚Äôve done that anyway whether or not they‚Äôd watched a violent movie or played a violent video game.

Oh crap ‚Äì I really didn‚Äôt want to get into a deep discussion about the film‚Äôs message and about whether the media has a responsibility to humanity to not glorify violence and blah blah blah. That‚Äôs one of those arguments that can go around in circles for an eternity. All I‚Äôll say is: Society is fucked. The media ‚Äì including movies, TV, video games, websites ‚Äì is just a reflection of society. It gives us what we seem to want based on our behavior. I think Natural Born Killers displays that logic perfectly but it‚Äôs a shame that its message, although extremely blatant, seemed to not be fully grasped by everyone at the time.

I think what worked for me with this movie besides the film‚Äôs message was its style. I loved the psychedelic scenes and Stone‚Äôs use of different colors. I thought the I Love Lucy sitcom-style scenes involving Rodney Dangerfield as the abusive father of Juliette Lewis were very inventive and the scene in the rattlesnake-filled desert was trippy. Hell, I even found the ‚Äúmarriage on the bridge‚Äù scene oddly romantic in a messed-up way. That‚Äôs the thing ‚Äì I think most people watching this movie find themselves liking Lewis‚Äô & Harrelson‚Äôs Mickey & Mallory despite the fact that they‚Äôre psychotic killers with no remorse. But that‚Äôs the whole point, of course. The media in the movie makes them stars and the movie itself has made their fictional characters stars. By the end, you want Mickey & Mallory to live happily ever after and THAT is truly fucked-up. That‚Äôs how good the movie is, though ‚Äì it turns us into the Mickey & Mallory-worshipping audience of American Maniacs.

My Rating: 8/10

***SPOILER FREE REVIEW***

Directed by Francis Lawrence

Based on Mockingjay by Suzanne Collins

Starring: Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson, Liam Hemsworth, Woody Harrelson, Elizabeth Banks, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Jeffrey Wright, Sam Claflin, Jena Malone, Stanley Tucci, Donald Sutherland

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDB)

As the war of Panem escalates to the destruction of other districts by the Capitol, Katniss Everdeen, the reluctant leader of the rebellion, must bring together an army against President Snow, while all she holds dear hangs in the balance.

My Opinion:

Well, I was attempting to take a week off from blogging but I just watched the final Hunger Games film so figured I should say something about it before the weekend (I also watched Steve Jobs this week but a review for that can wait until next week). Hmmmmmmmm‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 2‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Ä¶.. What can I say? I want to stay very spoiler-free, even for those who‚Äôve read the books as I‚Äôm sure the readers will be very curious to know if certain things get changed. But I‚Äôm not going to tell you! I can say that I‚Äôve read the books and was a very big fan (of the first two, at least. like most people). I also think the first two films are very good. These final two, though? Well‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll get to that more in a bit.

What‚Äôs interesting is that my husband, who hasn‚Äôt read the books, had quite a different reaction to this film than I did. He thought the first two were good but did NOT like these final two. He had a lot to say about it but I‚Äôm not going to go into any of that ‚Äì I just find it interesting that he disliked these final two so much & wonder if others who haven‚Äôt read the books will have the same reaction that he did. I think they probably will. I think they‚Äôll feel exactly the same way about the final two films as us book readers felt about the final book.

I think The Hunger Games book trilogy is fantastic. I know it‚Äôs ‚ÄúYA‚Äù, which puts some people off. But it‚Äôs nothing like things such as Twilight ‚Äì Collins is a great writer and the first two books are two of my very favorites that I‚Äôve read in the past decade or so. Yeah ‚Äì the first two. Not the final book. I think most readers felt the same way about that one.

I don‚Äôt know how to go about reviewing this movie as, for me, it‚Äôs impossible to review it on its own & not compare it to the book. No, I didn‚Äôt like the final book. So‚Ä¶ I was never going to love the final two movies (not helped by the fact that splitting one book into two movies pisses me the hell off). As a whole, though, these movies are quite faithful adaptations & that‚Äôs always very important to me. It‚Äôs been a long time since I read these but Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 2 is very faithful from what I remember (without giving away to the books‚Äô readers whether or not anything big was changed). So, I can‚Äôt fault the two Mockingjay films. They did what they could with them and remained pretty loyal to the source material. Which is great! It‚Äôs just unfortunate that the source material isn‚Äôt so great.

I haven‚Äôt reviewed the first film as I wasn‚Äôt blogging yet but I reviewed Catching Fire (HERE) and Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 1 (HERE). Catching Fire was really good (I gave it 8/10) but Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 1 felt pointless as there was no need to turn it into two films (I gave it 7/10). Part 2 is at least a bit better than Part 1 since you finally get a conclusion instead of being left hanging halfway through a story. I once again enjoyed re-visiting these characters & stand by my opinion that Jennifer Lawrence was the perfect choice to play Katniss (although the hubby thought she seemed bored in these last two films, which I don‚Äôt totally agree with but do admit that it did feel that way a little at times).

Elizabeth Banks & Woody Harrelson have very small roles in this final film, which is a shame as they‚Äôre two great characters. The character of Peeta is once again a bit of a bore (sorry if you like him! but his character is a bit bland). One big complaint I‚Äôve had all along & still have is that I don‚Äôt think they developed the character of Primrose (sister of Katniss) enough. Well, the books were kind of guilty of this as well if I remember correctly but they should have given more screen time to the two sisters and slightly less to the somewhat annoying love triangle. I don‚Äôt think the films fully gave you the sense of love that Katniss has for her sister and also felt they didn‚Äôt fully explain some important plot points to a movie audience that hasn‚Äôt read the books. I think I‚Äôd have been slightly lost during the two Mockingjay films if I hadn‚Äôt read the books.

Summary:

I really want to hear from you guys what you all thought of this one & whether or not you‚Äôve read the books. I‚Äôve not yet read any other reviews so don‚Äôt know what kind of reaction this movie is getting but I‚Äôd guess that those who haven‚Äôt read the books will feel the way that my hubby did & won‚Äôt really like this film. As I said, I can‚Äôt really fault this movie as it‚Äôs a good adaptation and I think they‚Äôve done a pretty great job in choosing the cast for this entire series (especially Lawrence). Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 2 is a good film but I kind of lost interest in it in the same way I did with the final book. Obviously you‚Äôll want to see it if you‚Äôve watched all the others but don‚Äôt expect it to be much different than Part 1. However you felt about Part 1, you‚Äôll probably feel the same about Part 2.

Sorry for that rather uninformative review! It‚Äôs a very hard one to talk about without spoiling things so feel free to discuss it with me further in the comments. üôÇ Just try to put a spoiler warning at the start.

My Rating: 7/10

Seven Psychopaths (2012)

Directed & Written by Martin McDonagh

Starring: Colin Farrell, Sam Rockwell, Woody Harrelson, Christopher Walken, Tom Waits, Abbie Cornish, Olga Kurylenko, ≈Ωeljko Ivanek

Plot Synopsis: (via IMDB)

A struggling screenwriter inadvertently becomes entangled in the Los Angeles criminal underworld after his oddball friends kidnap a gangster‚Äôs beloved Shih Tzu.

My Opinion:

I‚Äôd been meaning to watch this movie for a while as I really liked Martin McDonagh‚Äôs In Bruges. Unfortunately, I ended up being a little disappointed as Seven Psychopaths is definitely not as good as In Bruges. There are several fantastic moments, though, and some great performances from the impressive cast. In fact, I‚Äôd say there are a few moments of pure brilliance & I‚Äôll be sure to discuss the movie‚Äôs positives as well as the negatives. But, overall, I thought the main plot was a bit of a mess and far too convoluted.

In this movie, Colin Farrell‚Äôs character is a writer working on a screenplay called Seven Psychopaths. He hasn‚Äôt gotten very far with the script (I think he‚Äôd only managed to think up one out of the seven psychopaths if I remember correctly) so his friend (a dognapper played by Sam Rockwell) tries to help him out with the other six. Meanwhile, Rockwell (who kidnaps dogs for ‚Äúboss‚Äù Christopher Walken) has managed to anger a real-life psychopath (Woody Harrelson) after kidnapping his beloved dog.

What‚Äôs unfortunate is that this overall dognapping story is the main part of the plot yet it‚Äôs the weakest thing about the movie. The main story is messy & feels too forced. Okay ‚Äì part of this may somewhat be down to my dislike of Woody Harrelson. Aside from his ‚Äúdumb guy‚Äù character in Cheers, I‚Äôve never liked him in anything else. He just seemed very weak next to the likes of Walken and even Rockwell (who was fantastic in this). Colin Farrell was just his usual Colin Farrell self (I‚Äôm not a big fan of his either but he‚Äôs fine in this although his role could have been played by anyone).

The interesting thing about this movie, which I didn‚Äôt know beforehand, is that there are several other stories that get told throughout the film as ideas for further psychopathic characters are discussed. We witness these stories (such as the one with Tom Waits in the above photo) and, DAMN, these stories are good! I‚Äôd watch full movies of a few of these stories as they‚Äôre all far more interesting than the overall plot involving the dognapping & Woody Harrelson‚Äôs character. It reminded me a lot of Grindhouse & how the fake trailers looked so good that they ended up making movies of some of them (I didn‚Äôt watch Machete so I don‚Äôt know if that was any good but I really enjoyed Hobo With A Shotgun).

As well as these ‚Äústories within a story‚Äù, which I liked a hell of a lot, I really loved Christopher Walken & Sam Rockwell. I like Christopher Walken but he can be a little strange sometimes. I complained about him ‚Äúphoning it in‚Äù in my review of Things To Do In Denver When You‚Äôre Dead. He plays the same sort of character far too often but, although he‚Äôs playing that sort of character once again here, he gives such a perfect performance. His final scene is especially awesome as were the scenes with his character‚Äôs wife (played by a woman named Linda Bright Clay, who appears to have been in very little else. Why?! She‚Äôs fantastic in this! Another one of this movie‚Äôs highlights). Walken‚Äôs & Clay‚Äôs characters were both fantastic, as was their story. Well done to McDonagh on writing their parts.

Sam Rockwell was possibly the main highlight for me, though. At least, as far as the acting was concerned ‚Äì my favorite thing was definitely the ‚Äústories within a story‚Äù. I have a post about Rockwell scheduled for tomorrow & I say the same thing that I‚Äôll say now: I don‚Äôt think he‚Äôs really lucked out quite yet in getting that one ‚Äúperfect role‚Äù. When he does, I think he‚Äôll finally get the attention he deserves. This is definitely a defining role for him, however, and probably my second favorite performance of his. I‚Äôm starting to kind of finally see the reason he seems to have some pretty loyal fans. If you‚Äôre a fan of his but haven‚Äôt seen this movie for some reason, I highly recommend that you check it out.

Summary:

Seven Psychopaths is an odd one. It‚Äôs so good at times and just plain confusing at other times. I‚Äôm afraid that it tries a little too hard to be cool. I think it wants to be like something made by Tarantino but, although the clever dialogue is there and there are some very rich characters, the story is even more convoluted than that in Pulp Fiction. I‚Äôm struggling with rating this one as I think it deserves a higher score than I‚Äôll probably give it but I can‚Äôt ignore the fact that the main plot really didn‚Äôt hold my interest at all. But I‚Äôm in no way trying to talk people out of watching this one as I think parts of it are brilliant and the writing is far better than we get from most movies. I‚Äôd actually recommend this one as I think a lot of people reading this would like this movie quite a lot. If you like In Bruges or Things To Do In Denver When You‚Äôre Dead or anything from Tarantino, you‚Äôll definitely like this one as well. I guess I‚Äôd rather have a few moments of brilliance than a movie that‚Äôs mediocre the whole way through.

My Rating: 7/10

The Hunger Games: Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 1

Directed by Francis Lawrence

Based on Mockingjay by Suzanne Collins

Starring:

Jennifer Lawrence

Josh Hutcherson

Liam Hemsworth

Woody Harrelson

Elizabeth Banks

Julianne Moore

Philip Seymour Hoffman

Jeffrey Wright

Stanley Tucci

Donald Sutherland

Running time: 123 minutes

Plot Synopsis: (via Wikipedia)

The story continues to follow Katniss Everdeen; having twice survived the Hunger Games, Katniss finds herself in District 13. Under the leadership of President Coin and the advice of her trusted friends, Katniss reluctantly becomes the symbol of a mass rebellion against the Capitol and fights to save Peeta and a nation moved by her courage.

My Opinion:

I love YA fiction (especially of the post-apocalyptic dystopian sci-fi variety!) and have read The Hunger Games books. It was before this blog started but I did review the Catching Fire movie (HERE if you‚Äôre bothered). The first two books are possibly my favorite of the YA stuff I‚Äôve read in recent years and I think the first two films were very faithful, especially the second, and I‚Äôve been happy with them and with the choice of actors (other than maybe Josh Hutcherson). I‚Äôll admit that I‚Äôm not a big fan of the final book so I‚Äôm naturally unlikely to like these last two movies as much as the first two. However, from what I can remember of the final book now all these years later, I think this film again stayed pretty faithful. It‚Äôs a solid movie and everyone again does a good job with their roles but I still can‚Äôt help but feel a bit ‚Äúmeh, so what?‚Äù. It especially doesn‚Äôt help that they‚Äôve done that thoroughly annoying thing again of splitting the final book of a series into TWO movies. Why why why?! It‚Äôs not as annoying as the whole Hobbit bullshit but, seriously ‚Äì they‚Äôre doing it to get more money out of us as opposed to making sure to make the best piece of ‚Äúart‚Äù they can and it gets on my nerves.

Now that I got that little rant off my chest: Is The Hunger Games: Mockingjay ‚Äì Part Freaking 1 any good? Yes, it‚Äôs fine. I enjoy the story and seeing the characters again and still think Jennifer Lawrence is perfect for the role of Katniss (even though we‚Äôre starting to see her in too many movies and I‚Äôm afraid she could someday be on my annoying list instead of my favorites list). They have some very famous actors in these movies and it feels like they take their roles seriously as opposed to just ‚Äúphoning it in‚Äù, which it feels like famous actors do in some other YA films. I think it makes The Hunger Games movies feel a bit more ‚Äúgrown up‚Äù than others (which I see as a good thing). The final book is the darkest and the movies have been good at getting the tone right but, hopefully, no parents are letting anyone see these if they‚Äôre TOO young‚Ä¶

Summary:

I don‚Äôt think I need to go into this film much. If you liked the first two, you‚Äôll like this one even though you may be annoyed at again not getting any sort of ‚Äúconclusion‚Äù. If you like the books, you‚Äôll be happy enough with this adaptation. The acting is really good, especially for a ‚ÄúYA‚Äù film, and Lawrence is still the perfect Katniss. I understand that the story needed to take this direction in the final book and couldn‚Äôt just do the same thing once again but it just didn‚Äôt work as well for me and I don‚Äôt expect to like the final two films as much as the first two. Speaking of YA stuff, I saw The Maze Runner a couple weeks ago but haven‚Äôt had a chance to review it yet. Maybe Wednesday‚Ä¶. Yes! I‚Äôll make this a ‚Äúmovies based on novels‚Äù week here at CPD since I also just watched Odd Thomas! Anyway, although I think Mockingjay is the superior film, I kind of enjoyed The Maze Runner more as I haven‚Äôt read the books and liked watching a story unfold without already knowing what would happen. I‚Äôve watched Mockingjay as I want to see how they handle the books but I really wish they‚Äôd just made this into one film. But I‚Äôll of course shell out money once again this time next year to see Part 2. And I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll complain about that once again. üòâ

My Rating: 7/10

The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)

Directed by Francis Lawrence

Based on: Catching Fire by Suzanne Collins

Starring:

Jennifer Lawrence

Josh Hutcherson

Liam Hemsworth

Woody Harrelson

Elizabeth Banks

Lenny Kravitz

Philip Seymour Hoffman

Jeffrey Wright

Stanley Tucci

Donald Sutherland

Running time: 146 minutes

Plot synopsis:

After their victory in the 74th Hunger Games, Katniss Everdeen and Peeta Mellark have become symbols of hope to those in the Districts of Panem. President Snow will do whatever it takes to make sure that this hope doesn‚Äôt lead to a rebellion.

My Opinion:

I read the Hunger Games books and loooooved them (Well, loved the first two at least‚Ä¶). So I was very excited to see the films. I thought the first one was a very good adaptation and feel the same way about Catching Fire. I know they can never put absolutely everything from a book in the movie as there‚Äôs just not enough time ‚Äì As long as no major changes are made, I‚Äôm happy. It‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve read these but, from what I remember, Catching Fire is extremely faithful to the book so that should keep the fans happy.

I‚Äôd actually be more interested to know what people who haven‚Äôt read the books think of these films. I often try to read the book before the movie and all that but it does take a little fun out of the movie for me. I just like to be surprised & like not knowing what‚Äôs going to happen. I always enjoy seeing the movie bring a book ‚Äúto life‚Äù but‚Ä¶ I have no idea what point I‚Äôm trying to make here! Just that, you know ‚Äì I knew what was going to happen every step of the way.

However, both of these films have done a great job creating the overall look of this world and especially bringing these characters to the screen. I really can‚Äôt fault ANY of the casting. Jennifer Lawrence is absolutely perfect as Katniss Everdeen. She‚Äôs totally what I‚Äôd pictured while reading the books and she does an excellent job in these films (well, she IS an Oscar winner, you know). For a young adult series, it‚Äôs a very dark story and she does all the serious & emotional stuff brilliantly. I can‚Äôt really imagine anyone else in the role. And I think with these young adult adaptations, the actors don‚Äôt always take the material as seriously & it sometimes feels like the big name actors are only there for the paycheck & are giving a half-assed performance. I don‚Äôt feel this way with the Hunger Games films, though. Everyone seems to be giving their all.

Woody Harrelson ‚Äì Also perfect. He‚Äôs a great Haymitch and one of the biggest highlights of these films. I also love Lenny Kravitz as Cinna. Even though he‚Äôs not what I‚Äôd pictured from the books, he‚Äôs also one of the best characters in the films (for me). I also loved seeing Effie having a bit more depth in this one (and, again, I think Elizabeth Banks does this role very well).

Donald Sutherland, Stanley Tucci, Amanda Plummer, Jena Malone ‚Äì All good! Liam Hemsworth & Josh Hutcherson are both fine as Gale & Peeta but are the only ones that aren‚Äôt *quite* right for me (especially Hutcherson). However, both have grown on me & I fully see them as those characters now after this second film. I‚Äôd love to see Primrose get a lot more screen time ‚Äì I feel that the audience barely knows her if they‚Äôve not read the books. Also not 100% sure on Finnick or Philip Seymour Hoffman as Plutarch ‚Äì Hoffman was good but kind of just seemed his usual self.

Summary:

I know I‚Äôve not said anything about the story as, well, I know the whole story from the books. I loved the books ‚Äì the story was really intense and I couldn‚Äôt read them quick enough. Luckily, the films are the same way ‚Äì they‚Äôve been very faithful adaptations so far and I don‚Äôt think fans of the books can have any major complaints. The world looks great and, more importantly, the casting has been perfect. I really can‚Äôt complain about any of the actors at all but the ones they especially got right were Haymitch and, luckily, Katniss. If they‚Äôd gotten the wrong actress for Katniss, I don‚Äôt think these films would be quite as successful. Catching Fire is just as good as the first film (although you really can‚Äôt top the first film just as you can‚Äôt top the first book in the trilogy). If you haven‚Äôt read the books but liked the first film, you‚Äôll definitely like Catching Fire and you‚Äôll get a lot more character development than you did in the first film.

It‚Äôs going to be VERY interesting to see what they do with that final book‚Ä¶

My Rating: 8/10

Now You See Me

Directed by Louis Leterrier

Starring:

Jesse Eisenberg

Mark Ruffalo

Woody Harrelson

M√©lanie Laurent

Isla Fisher

Dave Franco

Michael Caine

Morgan Freeman

Michael Kelly

Common

Running time: 115 minutes

Plot Synopsis:

Four magicians, brought together by mysterious circumstances, are investigated by the FBI after performing a magic show together in which they seemingly pull off a bank heist.

My Quick Opinion:

I‚Äôll keep this short as, unfortunately, there‚Äôs not a lot to say about it. I went in with low expectations and knowing it was going to be a simple movie with a bit of magic that would at least keep me entertained for a couple of hours. I wasn‚Äôt exactly expecting The Prestige ‚Äì one of my all-time favorite films. But Now You See Me is a much further cry from the brilliance of that film than I was hoping.

Everyone does a decent enough job in their roles but the characters are very one-dimensional. I love Michael Caine and Morgan Freeman and always enjoy watching them but they‚Äôre wasted in this film. Woody Harrelson is probably the most entertaining of the four magicians but he‚Äôs really just doing the sort of role he often does. The actual highlight of the film is probably M√©lanie Laurent as an Interpol detective. But that could just be because I have a bit of a girl crush on her‚Ä¶ I felt they could have done a lot more with her character, though, as it didn‚Äôt feel very well developed. Same goes for Mark Ruffalo‚Äôs character. All of the characters in this felt very underdeveloped, actually. Disappointing.

Summary:

A lightweight ‚Äúmagic movie‚Äù that will keep you entertained for a couple of hours but won‚Äôt have you leaving the cinema asking any questions. Unlike The Prestige, which I thought about for days afterward. Hell, I still do. I left Now You See Me feeling quite empty, though, like the box after the rabbit has disappeared. (Ha! Was trying to get a ‚Äúmagic‚Äù reference in here somewhere. That was pathetic, though. Lol!).

I just expected a BIT more from such an impressive line-up of actors. At the very least, since the story and characters are a bit weak, I expected more really fun and cool MAGIC than we actually get. Mindless fun but a little TOO mindless. And once you‚Äôve seen it, I have a feeling that it‚Äôs one where things really don‚Äôt add up if you were to watch it a second time. But it‚Äôs really not worth the time thinking about too much ‚Äì this movie isn‚Äôt asking you to think about it beyond the final credits. Oh man ‚Äì I‚Äôm being more harsh than I‚Äôm meaning to be! It was a fun watch. Nothing less but certainly nothing more. Rent it.

My Rating: 6/10
